name: Generic Troubleshooting
description: General-purpose troubleshooting workflow for any issue type

questions.ask: What specific error or problem are you experiencing?
questions.guidance: Describe the exact error message, unexpected behavior, or issue you're encountering. Include error codes if available.
examples: Application returns 500 Internal Server Error when accessing /api/users endpoint
Database connection timeout after 30 seconds
Build fails with 'MODULE_NOT_FOUND' error

questions.ask: When did this problem first occur?
questions.guidance: Provide the date and time when the issue started. Note if it's intermittent or consistent.
examples: Started January 5th around 3:00 PM UTC, happens every time now
Began after deployment on January 6th at 10:30 AM
Intermittent failures starting last week, occurs about 30% of the time

questions.ask: What changes were made before the problem started?
questions.guidance: List any recent deployments, configuration changes, dependency updates, or infrastructure modifications. If nothing changed, state that explicitly.
examples: Updated Node.js from v16 to v18 and deployed new code version
Changed database connection string in configuration
No changes made - issue appeared spontaneously

questions.ask: What have you tried to resolve this issue?
questions.guidance: Describe troubleshooting steps already attempted, including restarts, rollbacks, or configuration changes.
examples: Restarted the application service twice, checked logs, verified credentials
Rolled back to previous version but issue persists
Nothing yet - just discovered the issue

questions.ask: What is the expected behavior versus actual behavior?
questions.guidance: Clearly describe what should happen versus what is actually happening.
examples: Expected: API returns user data in JSON format. Actual: Returns empty response with 200 status
Expected: Page loads in under 2 seconds. Actual: Takes 30+ seconds or times out
Expected: Data saved to database. Actual: Save operation fails silently

questions.ask: What environment is affected (production, staging, development)?
questions.guidance: Specify which environment(s) are experiencing the issue. Note if the issue occurs in all environments or just specific ones.
examples: Production only - staging and dev work fine
All environments affected
Development environment - haven't deployed to staging yet

questions.ask: Are there any relevant log messages or error details?
questions.guidance: Include relevant log excerpts, stack traces, or error details. Focus on entries around the time the problem occurred.
examples: Error: ECONNREFUSED at TCPConnectWrap.afterConnect
SQL Exception: Invalid object name 'Users'
No error logs found - application runs but produces incorrect results

initialHypotheses.hypothesis: Configuration values (connection strings, API keys, environment variables) are incorrect or missing
initialHypotheses.reasoning: Configuration issues are the most common cause of failures after deployments or environment changes
investigationSteps: Verify all required configuration values are present
Check if configuration differs between working and non-working environments
Validate credentials and connection strings are correct and not expired

initialHypotheses.hypothesis: A recent change (code, configuration, or infrastructure) introduced the issue
initialHypotheses.reasoning: Most issues correlate with recent changes to the system
investigationSteps: Review recent deployments, commits, or configuration changes
Compare current state with last known working version
Attempt rollback to previous version to verify if issue resolves

initialHypotheses.hypothesis: Resource constraints (memory, CPU, disk, connections) are being exceeded
initialHypotheses.reasoning: Resource exhaustion can cause failures, timeouts, and performance degradation
investigationSteps: Check resource utilization metrics (CPU, memory, disk space, network)
Review connection pool sizes and limits
Analyze if issue correlates with high load or usage patterns

initialHypotheses.hypothesis: External dependencies (APIs, databases, services) are unavailable or failing
initialHypotheses.reasoning: Systems often rely on external services that may be down or degraded
investigationSteps: Test connectivity to all external dependencies
Check status pages or monitoring for dependent services
Verify network connectivity and firewall rules

initialHypotheses.hypothesis: Permission or authentication issues are preventing required operations
initialHypotheses.reasoning: Access control problems frequently cause authorization and operation failures
investigationSteps: Verify service accounts and credentials have necessary permissions
Check for expired certificates or tokens
Review audit logs for permission denied errors
